name: Acorn Woodpecker

power.text: Gain 1 [seed] from the birdfeeder, if available. You may cache it on this bird.

flavorText: In a single dead tree, these birds may drill as many as 50,000 holes for storing acorns.

name: American Avocet

power.text: When another player takes the "lay eggs" action, lay 1 [egg] on another bird with a [ground] nest.

flavorText: American avocets build their own nests, but they also parasitize other birds' nests.

name: American Bittern

power.text: Player(s) with the fewest birds in their [wetland] draw 1 [card].

flavorText: Bitterns hide in reeds and cattails, where they are well camouflaged.

name: American Coot

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, draw 1 [card].

flavorText: These omnivorous birds eat a lot of algae, but also seeds, fish, insects, and mollusks.

name: American Crow

power.text: Discard 1 [egg] from any of your other birds to gain 1 [wild] from the supply.

flavorText: These intelligent birds steal eggs and food from other birds, and cache food for later.

name: American Goldfinch

power.text: Gain 3 [seed] from the supply.

flavorText: Goldfinches breed late, after the milkweek and thistle have gone to seed.

name: American Kestrel

power.text: Roll all dice not in birdfeeder. If any are [rodent], cache 1 [rodent] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: Kestrels track rodents by their urine and will cache surplus kills for later.

name: American Oystercatcher

power.text: Draw [card] equal to the number of players +1. Starting with you and proceeding clockwise, each player selects 1 of those cards and places it in their hand. You keep the extra card.

flavorText: These birds feed not just on oysters and shellfish but also other invertebrates.

name: American Redstart

power.text: Gain 1 [die] from the birdfeeder.

flavorText: Redstarts get their name from the Old English word "steart," meaning tail.

name: American Robin

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, draw 1 [card].

flavorText: Robins have been known to roost in groups of a hundred thousand or more.

name: American White Pelican

power.text: Discard 1 [fish] to tuck 2 [card] from the deck behind this bird.

flavorText: Pelicans work together to herd fish and then scoop them up.

name: American Woodcock
flavorText: The woodcock's amazing mating display involves repeated dives from 90 meters.

name: Anhinga

power.text: Roll all dice not in birdfeeder. If any are [fish], cache 1 [fish] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: This bird is called "snakebird"---it swims with only head and neck above water.

name: Anna's Hummingbird

power.text: Each player gains 1 [die] from the birdfeeder, starting with the player of your choice.

flavorText: These birds' impressive mating displays involve diving from over 30 meters in the air.

name: Ash-Throated Flycatcher

power.text: Lay 1 [egg] on each of your birds with a [cavity] nest.

flavorText: These birds are adapted to dry places: they get all their water from their food.

name: Atlantic Puffin

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: Puffins' breeding areas are threatened by climate change.

name: Baird's Sparrow

power.text: Lay 1 [egg] on any bird.

flavorText: Spencer Fullerton Baird was the first curator of the Smithsonian.

name: Bald Eagle

power.text: Gain all [fish] that are in the birdfeeder.

flavorText: Bald eagles steal fish. Benjamin Franklin thought this was a bad choice for the US national bird.

name: Baltimore Oriole

power.text: All players gain 1 [fruit] from the supply.

flavorText: Orioles weave pouch nests that hang from a tree nest.

name: Barn Owl

power.text: Roll all dice not in birdfeeder. If any are [rodent], cache 1 [rodent] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: Barn owls use their excellent hearing to catch prey in the dark and will cache surplus for later.

name: Barn Swallow

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, draw 1 [card].

flavorText: Barn swallows once nested in caves but now favor human-made structures.

name: Barred Owl

power.text: Look at a [card] from the deck. If less than 75cm, tuck it behind this bird. If not, discard it.

flavorText: The barred owl's haunting call sounds like "Who cooks for you?"

name: Barrow's Goldeneye

power.text: When another player takes the "lay eggs" action, lay 1 [egg] on another bird with a [cavity] nest.

flavorText: These ducks will lay their eggs in the nest of any cavity-nesting duck.

name: Bell's Vireo

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: John Graham Bell taught taxidermy to future US President Theodore Roosevelt.

name: Belted Kingfisher

power.text: When another player plays a bird in their [wetland], gain 1 [fish] from the supply.

flavorText: A kingfisher burrow can go up to 2 meters into a riverbank and slopes to shed water.

name: Bewick's Wren

power.text: If this bird is to the right of all other birds in its habitat, move it to another habitat.

flavorText: These wrens have largely disappeared in the eastern part of their range due to nest predation.

name: Black Skimmer

power.text: Roll all dice not in birdfeeder. If any are [fish], cache 1 [fish] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: Skimmers plow the water with their beaks, snapping shut when they hit a fish.

name: Black Tern

power.text: Draw 1 [card]. If you do, discard 1 [card] from your hand at the end of your turn.

flavorText: These terns build floating nests out of marsh plants.

name: Black Vulture

power.text: When another player's [predator] succeeds, gain 1 [die] from the birdfeeder.

flavorText: Turkey vultures have a better sense of smell, so black vultures follow them to food.

name: Black-Bellied Whistling-Duck

power.text: Discard 1 [seed] to tuck 2 [card] from the deck behind this bird.

flavorText: These ducks really do whistle.

name: Black-Billed Magpie

power.text: When another player's [predator] succeeds, gain 1 [die] from the birdfeeder.

flavorText: These omnivores steal eggs and eat carrion along with a diversity of other foods.

name: Black-Chinned Hummingbird

power.text: All players gain 1 [fruit] from the supply.

flavorText: To display, males of this species will fly up 30 m then dive, reaching speeds near 100 kilometers per hour.

name: Black-Crowned Night-Heron

power.text: Discard 1 [egg] from any of your other birds to gain 1 [wild] from the supply.

flavorText: Night herons eat carrion and eggs in addition to fish, rodents, and invertebrates.

name: Black-Necked Stilt

power.text: Draw 2 [card].

flavorText: When not breeding, stilts form closely packed groups and will mob predators.

name: Blue Grosbeak

power.text: If this bird is to the right of all other birds in its habitat, move it to another habitat.

flavorText: Grosbeaks especially like tangled vines and shrubby areas on forest edges.

name: Blue Jay

power.text: Gain 1 [seed] from the birdfeeder, if available. You may cache it on this bird.

flavorText: Blue jays can carry up to 5 acorns at a time and will store hundreds for winter.

name: Blue-Gray Gnatcatcher

power.text: Gain 1 [invertebrate] from the supply.

flavorText: Gnatcatchers' breeding range is steadily shifting north with climate change.

name: Blue-Winged Warbler
flavorText: This warbler especially likes to nest on the edges between forest and fields.

name: Bobolink

power.text: Lay 1 [egg] on each of your birds with a [ground] nest.

flavorText: Emily Dickinson wrote poems about these birds as rowdy choristers in her church of nature.

name: Brant

power.text: Draw the 3 face-up [card] in the bird tray.

flavorText: Brants can migrate the 5300 kilometers from Alaska to Mexico in 54 hours.

name: Brewer's Blackbird

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, you may also lay 1 [egg] on this bird.

flavorText: Brewer was a prominent 19th-century ornithologist and oologist.

name: Broad-Winged Hawk

power.text: Roll all dice not in birdfeeder. If any are [rodent], cache 1 [rodent] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: This hawk is seen more during migration than when it's in the forest interior.

name: Bronzed Cowbird

power.text: When another player takes the "lay eggs" action, lay 1 [egg] on a bird with a [bowl] nest.

flavorText: Cowbirds lay eggs in other birds' nests and often break or push out the host bird's eggs.

name: Brown Pelican

power.text: Gain 3 [fish] from the supply.

flavorText: Seriously endangered in the 1970s, brown pelicans are thriving after the US and Canada banned DDT.

name: Brown-Headed Cowbird

power.text: When another player takes the "lay eggs" action, lay 1 [egg] on a bird with a [bowl] nest.

flavorText: Cowbirds do not make nests; they lay their eggs in other birds' nests.

name: Burrowing Owl

power.text: Roll all dice not in birdfeeder. If any are [rodent], cache 1 [rodent] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: These owls often use old prairie dog burrows for their underground nests.

name: Bushtit

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, you may also lay 1 [egg] on this bird.

flavorText: Bushtits live in flocks, and single adults will help couples raise their young.

name: California Condor

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: There were just 22 of these scavengers alive in the 1980s, but now there are over 500.

name: California Quail

power.text: Lay 1 [egg] on this bird.

flavorText: California quail nests have been reported with as many as 28 eggs.

name: Canada Goose

power.text: Discard 1 [seed] to tuck 2 [card] from the deck behind this bird.

flavorText: The oldest known Canada Goose was at least 33 years old.

name: Canvasback

power.text: All players draw 1 [card] from the deck.

flavorText: The fastest recorded canvasback was flying 116 kilometers per hour.

name: Carolina Chickadee

power.text: Cache 1 [seed] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: Chickadees hide seeds and can remember thousands of hiding places.

name: Carolina Wren

power.text: Draw 2 [card].

flavorText: A single male Carolina Wren can sing nearly 3,000 times in a single day.

name: Cassin's Finch

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: Fifteen birds are named after ornithologist John Cassin, including 2 in this game.

name: Cassin's Sparrow

power.text: Lay 1 [egg] on any bird.

flavorText: Ornithologist Josh Cassin died from years of handling arsenic-preserved birds.

name: Cedar Waxwing

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, gain 1 [fruit] from the supply.

flavorText: These birds secrete red wax on the tips of their wing feathers.

name: Cerulean Warbler

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: Between 1966 and 2015, this species lost 74% of its population.

name: Chestnut-Collared Longspur

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: This bird's population dropped by 82% between 1966 and 2015.

name: Chihuahuan Raven

power.text: Discard 1 [egg] from any of your other birds to gain 2 [wild] from the supply.

flavorText: This bird is native to the Chihuahuan Desert of the southwest US and northern Mexico.

name: Chimney Swift

power.text: If this bird is to the right of all other birds in its habitat, move it to another habitat.

flavorText: These birds have adapted to nest in chimneys instead of hollow trees.

name: Chipping Sparrow

power.text: Lay 1 [egg] on any bird.

flavorText: These sparrows generally feed on open ground, but near trees.

name: Clark's Grebe

power.text: Draw 1 [card]. If you do, discard 1 [card] from your hand at the end of your turn.

flavorText: Clark was a 19th-century surveyor who collected specimens for the Smithsonian.

name: Clark's Nutcracker

power.text: Gain 1 [seed] from the birdfeeder, if available. You may cache it on this bird.

flavorText: These birds are omnivorous but cache thousands of pine seeds for the winter.

name: Common Grackle

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, you may also lay 1 [egg] on this bird.

flavorText: In winter, grackles roost in large flocks that can include millions of individuals.

name: Common Loon

power.text: Player(s) with the fewest birds in their [wetland] draw 1 [card].

flavorText: Loon chicks spend the majority of their first week of life riding on a parent's back.

name: Common Merganser

power.text: Roll all dice not in birdfeeder. If any are [fish], cache 1 [fish] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: Adult males can eat fish more than a foot long.

name: Common Nighthawk

power.text: If this bird is to the right of all other birds in its habitat, move it to another habitat.

flavorText: Nighthawks are crepuscular, hunting flying insects at dawn and dusk.

name: Common Raven

power.text: Discard 1 [egg] from any of your other birds to gain 2 [wild] from the supply.

flavorText: Ravens are omnivores whose diet includes insects, rodents, eggs, birds, and carrion.

name: Common Yellowthroat

power.text: Draw 2 [card]. If you do, discard 1 [card] from your hand at the end of your turn.

flavorText: This was one of the first American birds to be cataloged by Linnaeus, in 1766.

name: Cooper's Hawk

power.text: Look at a [card] from the deck. If less than 75cm, tuck it behind this bird. If not, discard it.

flavorText: Cooper's hawks hunt forest birds and mammals with great stealth.

name: Dark-Eyed Junco

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, gain 1 [seed] from the supply.

flavorText: Juncos summer in the cool woods but will use more open habitats in the winter.

name: Dickcissel

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, you may also lay 1 [egg] on this bird.

flavorText: This bird used to live in the eastern US, but its range has shrunk due to habitat loss.

name: Double-Crested Cormorant

power.text: Discard 1 [fish] to tuck 2 [card] from the deck behind this bird.

flavorText: Cormorant colonies can be so dense that their guano kills the trees.

name: Downy Woodpecker

power.text: Play an additional bird in your [forest]. Pay its normal cost.

flavorText: This little woodpecker frequently joins mixed flocks.

name: Eastern Bluebird

power.text: Play an additional bird in your [grassland]. Pay its normal cost.

flavorText: Bluebirds struggle to breed when there is a lack of tree cavities. Nest boxed help.

name: Eastern Kingbird

power.text: When another player plays a bird in their [forest], gain 1 [invertebrate] from the supply.

flavorText: The kingbird displays its orange crown while defending its territory.

name: Eastern Phoebe

power.text: All players gain 1 [invertebrate] from the supply.

flavorText: Phoebes use mud to attach nests to riverbanks, rocky outcrops, or human structures.

name: Eastern Screech-Owl

power.text: Roll all dice not in birdfeeder. If any are [rodent], cache 1 [rodent] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: These owls live near humans, but because they're small and nocturnal, they're rarely seen.

name: Ferruginous Hawk

power.text: Roll all dice not in birdfeeder. If any are [rodent], cache 1 [rodent] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: These rust-colored birds sometimes hunt in groups in prairie dog towns.

name: Fish Crow

power.text: Discard 1 [egg] from any of your other birds to gain 1 [wild] from the supply.

flavorText: These birds may eat more fish than other crows, but they're actually omnivores.

name: Forster's Tern

power.text: Draw 1 [card]. If you do, discard 1 [card] from your hand at the end of your turn.

flavorText: These birds nest on the ground, on rafts of floating vegetation, or on muskrat lodges.

name: Franklin's Gull

power.text: Discard 1 [egg] to draw 2 [card].

flavorText: These gulls make floating nests of plant material on prairie marshes.

name: Golden Eagle

power.text: Look at a [card] from the deck. If less than 100cm, tuck it behind this bird. If not, discard it.

flavorText: Golden eagles mostly eat rabbit-sized prey but can go after livestock and birds.

name: Grasshopper Sparrow

power.text: Lay 1 [egg] on any bird.

flavorText: The song of these sparrows is often mistaken for grasshoppers.

name: Gray Catbird

power.text: Repeat a brown power on another bird in this habitat.

flavorText: Catbirds mimic other birds, and they also have a call that sounds like a cat meowing.

name: Great Blue Heron

power.text: Play an additional bird in your [wetland]. Pay its normal cost.

flavorText: Great blue herons form rookeries with egrets, cormorants, and other herons.

name: Great Crested Flycatcher

power.text: Gain 1 [invertebrate] from the birdfeeder, if available.

flavorText: These birds avoid competition by focusing on insects high up in trees.

name: Great Egret

power.text: Play an additional bird in your [wetland]. Pay its normal cost.

flavorText: Smaller birds will sometimes follow after great egrets as they stir up prey.

name: Great Horned Owl

power.text: Look at a [card] from the deck. If less than 100cm, tuck it behind this bird. If not, discard it.

flavorText: These strong owls can kill large prey including skunks, cats, and dogs.

name: Greater Prairie-Chicken

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: One subspecies of this bird went extinct in 1932, and a Texas form is endangered.

name: Greater Roadrunner

power.text: Look at a [card] from the deck. If less than 50cm, tuck it behind this bird. If not, discard it.

flavorText: Roadrunners rarely fly, but will jump up to snatch prey out of the air.

name: Green Heron

power.text: Trade 1 [wild] for any other type from the supply.

flavorText: Green herons drop insects and other objects onto the water to attract fish.

name: Hermit Thrush

power.text: Player(s) with the fewest birds in their [forest] gain 1 [die] from birdfeeder.

flavorText: Hermit thrushes tend to nest on the ground in the western US and in trees in the East.

name: Hooded Merganser

power.text: Repeat 1 [predator] power in this habitat.

flavorText: Merganser chicks jump from their cavity nest to the ground when they're just 1 day old.

name: Hooded Warbler
flavorText: This bird spends its time in the understory and nests within a meter of the ground.

name: Horned Lark

power.text: When another player plays a bird in their [grassland], tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird.

flavorText: Horned larks form large nomadic flocks, mixing with birds of other species.

name: House Finch

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, draw 1 [card].

flavorText: These finches are rarely alone and can flock in the hundreds.

name: House Wren

power.text: Play an additional bird in this bird's habitat. Pay its normal cost.

flavorText: House wrens will remove the eggs of other birds and take over their nests.

name: Inca Dove

power.text: Lay 1 [egg] on each of your birds with a [platform] nest.

flavorText: This bird likes human settlements and is expanding its range north.

name: Indigo Bunting

power.text: Gain 1 [invertebrate] or [fruit] from the birdfeeder, if available.

flavorText: Indigo buntings are almost always found on forest edges.

name: Juniper Titmouse

power.text: Cache 1 [seed] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: These little birds make it through winter by storing seeds.

name: Killdeer

power.text: Discard 1 [egg] to draw 2 [card].

flavorText: Killdeers will fake a broken wing to lure predators from their nests.

name: King Rail

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: King rails declined 90% from 1966 to 2015, due to habitat loss and pesticide runoff.

name: Lazuli Bunting

power.text: All players lay 1 [egg] on any 1 [bowl] bird. You may lay 1 [egg] on 1 additional [bowl] bird.

flavorText: The Latin name amoena means "beautiful" or "charming".

name: Lincoln's Sparrow

power.text: If this bird is to the right of all other birds in its habitat, move it to another habitat.

flavorText: Thomas Lincoln collected this sparrow in Canada with John James Audubon.

name: Loggerhead Shrike

power.text: When another player takes the "gain food" action, if they gain any number of [rodent], cache 1 [rodent] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: Shrikes impale their prey on thorse or barbed wire and may save them for later.

name: Mallard

power.text: Draw 1 [card].

flavorText: Mallards are among the most abundant ducks in the world.

name: Mississippi Kite

power.text: Roll all dice not in birdfeeder. If any are [rodent], cache 1 [rodent] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: These birds mostly eat large insects, but they'll also eat rodents, bats, and birds.

name: Mountain Bluebird

power.text: Play an additional bird in your [grassland]. Pay its normal cost.

flavorText: These birds can be found from prairies up to alpine zones above treeline.

name: Mountain Chickadee

power.text: Cache 1 [seed] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: Mountain chickadees are generally found in the conifer forests of the American West.

name: Mourning Dove

power.text: Lay 1 [egg] on this bird.

flavorText: One pair of doves may raise 5 or 6 small broods in a year.

name: Northern Bobwhite

power.text: Lay 1 [egg] on this bird.

flavorText: Bobwhites are prolific breeders, but their numbers are in decline.

name: Northern Cardinal

power.text: Gain 1 [fruit] from the supply.

flavorText: In most North American species, only males sing, but female cardinals break this rule.

name: Northern Flicker

power.text: Gain all [invertebrate] that are in the birdfeeder.

flavorText: These woodpeckers seek out ground-dwelling insects rather than pecking wood.

name: Northern Harrier

power.text: Look at a [card] from the deck. If less than 75cm, tuck it behind this bird. If not, discard it.

flavorText: Northern harriers fly low over marshes and grasslands seeking prey.

name: Northern Mockingbird

power.text: Repeat a brown power on another bird in this habitat.

flavorText: A male mockingbird may learn around 200 songs throughout its life.

name: Northern Shoveler

power.text: All players draw 1 [card] from the deck.

flavorText: The shoveler's large bill strains invertebrates from the water.

name: Osprey

power.text: All players gain 1 [fish] from the supply.

flavorText: Ospreys are excellent hunters, catching a fish in at least 1 out of every 4 dives.

name: Painted Bunting

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: Poachers sell these birds as pets, making it harder for wild populations to thrive.

name: Painted Whitestart

power.text: Gain 1 [invertebrate] from the supply.

flavorText: When they forage, whitestarts will flick their wings or tails to flush insects.

name: Peregrine Falcon

power.text: Look at a [card] from the deck. If less than 100cm, tuck it behind this bird. If not, discard it.

flavorText: Diving to attack, a peregrine falcon can reach speeds up to 320 kilometers per hour.

name: Pied-Billed Grebe

power.text: Draw 2 [card]. If you do, discard 1 [card] from your hand at the end of your turn.

flavorText: Pied-billed grebes create a floating platform nest with plant material.

name: Pileated Woodpecker

power.text: All players lay 1 [egg] on any 1 [cavity] bird. You may lay 1 [egg] on 1 additional [cavity] bird.

flavorText: Other birds use these birds' old nests and glean bugs where they've been feeding.\

name: Pine Siskin

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, gain 1 [seed] from the supply.

flavorText: Pine siskins are gregarious, traveling in flocks to look for food.

name: Prothonotary Warbler
flavorText: The name prothonotary comes from Catholic scribes who wore yellow robes.

name: Purple Gallinule

power.text: All players draw 1 [card] from the deck.

flavorText: With its long toes, this bird can walk on lily pads without sinking.

name: Purple Martin

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, draw 1 [card].

flavorText: Native Americans hung gourds as houses for these birds, because they eat so many bugs.

name: Pygmy Nuthatch

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, gain 1 [invertebrate] or [seed] from the supply.

flavorText: These flocking birds often have "helper" birds bringing food during nesting season.

name: Red Crossbill

power.text: All players gain 1 [seed] from the supply.

flavorText: These birds use their specialized bills to pry apart conifer seed cones.

name: Red-Bellied Woodpecker

power.text: Gain 1 [seed] from the birdfeeder, if available. You may cache it on this bird.

flavorText: These birds' tongues each out 5 centimeters for insects, but seeds are half their diet.

name: Red-Breasted Merganser

power.text: Draw 2 [card]. If you do, discard 1 [card] from your hand at the end of your turn.

flavorText: A red-breasted merganser was recorded flying 160 kilometers per hour, the fastest of any duck.

name: Red-Breasted Nuthatch

power.text: Cache 1 [seed] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: These birds put resin around their nest opening to keep out attackers.

name: Red-Cockaded Woodpecker

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: This bird is endangered due to habitat loss; there may be fewer than 10,000.

name: Red-Eyed Vireo

power.text: Play an additional bird in your [forest]. Pay its normal cost.

flavorText: Nearsighted vireos flock with other birds that make noise if predators are around.

name: Red-Headed Woodpecker

power.text: Gain 1 [seed] from the birdfeeder, if available. You may cache it on this bird.

flavorText: These woodpeckers store nuts, seeds, and insects in wood or under bark.

name: Red-Shouldered Hawk

power.text: Look at a [card] from the deck. If less than 75cm, tuck it behind this bird. If not, discard it.

flavorText: These hawks hunt from a perch, swooping down when prey is nearby.

name: Red-Tailed Hawk

power.text: Look at a [card] from the deck. If less than 75cm, tuck it behind this bird. If not, discard it.

flavorText: Movies almost always use the red-tailed hawk's call for any raptor.

name: Red-Winged Blackbird

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, you may also lay 1 [egg] on this bird.

flavorText: Blackbird flocks can include hundreds of thousands of birds

name: Ring-Billed Gull

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, draw 1 [card].

flavorText: These gulls steal food and eggs from other birds and scavenge at garbage dumps.

name: Rose-Breasted Grosbeak

power.text: Gain 1 [seed] or [fruit] from the birdfeeder, if available.

flavorText: This pretty, sweet-sounding bird has the gruesome nickname "cut-throat".

name: Roseate Spoonbill

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: This bird's unusually shaped bill helps it feel prey in the water.

name: Ruby-Crowned Kinglet

power.text: Play an additional bird in your [forest]. Pay its normal cost.

flavorText: Kinglets' ruby-red crown feathers pop up when they are agitated.

name: Ruby-Throated Hummingbird

power.text: Each player gains 1 [die] from the birdfeeder, starting with the player of your choice.

flavorText: Hummingbirds feed on nectar---but they also eat many small insects.

name: Ruddy Duck

power.text: Draw 2 [card]. If you do, discard 1 [card] from your hand at the end of your turn.

flavorText: To display for mates, male slap their blue bills on their chests and run across the water.

name: Sandhill Crane

power.text: Discard 1 [seed] to tuck 2 [card] from the deck behind this bird.

flavorText: Sandhill cranes can live for decades and mate for life.

name: Savannah Sparrow

power.text: Play an additional bird in your [grassland]. Pay its normal cost.

flavorText: This sparrow is named after both Savannah, Georgia, and Sandwich Sound, Alaska.

name: Say's Phoebe

power.text: Lay 1 [egg] on each of your birds with a [bowl] nest.

flavorText: Thomas Say also has snails, crabs, and a snake named after him.

name: Scaled Quail

power.text: Lay 1 [egg] on this bird.

flavorText: Quail chicks can get up and follow their parents as soon as they hatch.

name: Scissor-Tailed Flycatcher

power.text: All players gain 1 [invertebrate] from the supply.

flavorText: The mating display of these birds involves aerial acrobatics that show off their long tails.

name: Snowy Egret

power.text: Roll all dice not in birdfeeder. If any are [fish], cache 1 [fish] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: In the 1880's, these birds' wispy plumes were literally worth their weight in gold.

name: Song Sparrow

power.text: If this bird is to the right of all other birds in its habitat, move it to another habitat.

flavorText: When resources are abundant, song sparrows can rear four clutches of eggs in a year.

name: Spotted Owl

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: Habitat for these birds was a topic in logging fights in the Pacific Northwest region of the US.

name: Spotted Sandpiper

power.text: All players draw 1 [card] from the deck.

flavorText: These sandpipers consistently bob their tails; people call them teeter-peeps and tip-tails.

name: Spotted Towhee

power.text: Gain 1 [seed] from the supply.

flavorText: These birds forage by hopping backwards to uncover insects and seeds in the leaf litter.

name: Sprague's Pipit

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: This rare bird's mating display can last for over an hour.

name: Steller's Jay

power.text: Gain 1 [seed] from the birdfeeder, if available. You may cache it on this bird.

flavorText: Naturalist Georg Steller saw this bird on a Russian exploration to Alaska in 1741.

name: Swainson's Hawk

power.text: Look at a [card] from the deck. If less than 75cm, tuck it behind this bird. If not, discard it.

flavorText: These hawks feed chicks small mammals and birds, but adults eat mostly insects.

name: Tree Swallow

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, draw 1 [card].

flavorText: Tree swallows can form flocks numbering in the hundreds of thousands.

name: Trumpeter Swan
flavorText: With a mass over 9 kilograms, trumpeter swans are the heaviest bird in North America.

name: Tufted Titmouse

power.text: Play an additional bird in your [forest]. Pay its normal cost.

flavorText: Titmice are key in the formation of mixed-species flocks.

name: Turkey Vulture

power.text: When another player's [predator] succeeds, gain 1 [die] from the birdfeeder.

flavorText: Turkey vultures can projectile vomit to defend themselves.

name: Vaux's Swift

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, gain 1 [invertebrate] from the supply.

flavorText: William Sansom Vaux was a wealthy mineralogist and naturalist.

name: Violet-Green Swallow

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, draw 1 [card].

flavorText: Like other swallows, these birds forage in large groups in open areas.

name: Western Meadowlark

power.text: All players lay 1 [egg] on any 1 [ground] bird. You may lay 1 [egg] on 1 additional [ground] bird.

flavorText: This pretty bird also has a beautiful flute-like song.

name: Western Tanager

power.text: Gain 1 [invertebrate] or [fruit] from the birdfeeder, if available.

flavorText: These flame-colored birds are hard to see because they like the canopies of evergreen forests.

name: White-Breasted Nuthatch

power.text: Cache 1 [seed] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: Nuthatches cache seeds for winter in the bark of a tree.

name: White-Crowned Sparrow

power.text: If this bird is to the right of all other birds in its habitat, move it to another habitat.

flavorText: These sparrows like shrubby areas in many habitats, from tundra to desert.

name: White-Faced Ibis

power.text: Roll all dice not in birdfeeder. If any are [fish], cache 1 [fish] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: White-faced herons nest in colonies with herons and egrets.

name: White-Throated Swift

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, lay 1 [egg] on any bird.

flavorText: The white-throated swift is one of the fastest birds in North America.

name: Whooping Crane

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: From its low of 20 birds, the whooping crane population has risen to about 600.

name: Wild Turkey
flavorText: Wild turkeys were domesticated in the Americas before European contact.

name: Willet

power.text: Roll all dice not in birdfeeder. If any are [fish], cache 1 [fish] from the supply on this bird.

flavorText: Willets feed during the day and the night.

name: Wilson's Snipe

power.text: All players draw 1 [card] from the deck.

flavorText: Due to the position of their eyes, Wilson's snipes can see predators approaching from the front and back.

name: Wood Duck

power.text: Draw 2 [card]. If you do, discard 1 [card] from your hand at the end of your turn.

flavorText: Wood ducks nest in tree cavities in wooded areas.

name: Wood Stork

power.text: Draw 2 new bonus cards and keep 1.

flavorText: The wood stork was removed from the US endangered species list in 2014.

name: Yellow-Bellied Sapsucker

power.text: Gain 1 [invertebrate] from the supply.

flavorText: Sapsuckers drill rows of holes in trees, then they lap up the sap and the insects it attracts.

name: Yellow-Billed Cuckoo

power.text: When another player takes the "lay eggs" action, lay 1 [egg] on a bird with a [bowl] nest.

flavorText: Yellow-billed cuckoos lay their eggs in other birds' nests when food is abundant.

name: Yellow-Breasted Chat

power.text: If this bird is to the right of all other birds in its habitat, move it to another habitat.

flavorText: Because these birds like dense thickets, they are more often heard than seen.

name: Yellow-Headed Blackbird

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, you may also lay 1 [egg] on this bird.

flavorText: These blackbirds form huge flocks, especially in winter.

name: Yellow-Rumped Warbler

power.text: Tuck 1 [card] from your hand behind this bird. If you do, draw 1 [card].

flavorText: Birders sometimes call these birds "butterbutts."
